Legal_Issue: Failure to consider discretion under subsection 76(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, subsection 76(3)
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant provided reasons for favorable discretion; Officer did not assess them
Decision_Outcome: Visa denied due to insufficient points
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate error in decision-making process
Legal_Rule: A Visa Officer may exercise discretion under subsection 76(3) if the point system does not reflect an applicant's ability to become economically established in Canada
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness, failure to apply subsection 76(3) discretion
Outcome_on_Merits: Not decided on merits; remanded for reconsideration
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Officer failed to afford procedural fairness by not considering discretion
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's submission regarding economic establishment potential
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Visa denial based solely on points without discretion
Legal_Rule_Source: Subsection 76(3), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Outcome: Decision overturned, referred back for reconsideration
Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 76(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Insufficient points under economic class criteria
Applicable_Process: Economic immigration assessment with discretionary consideration
Governing_Rule: Subsection 76(3), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
